name.text: Free your creativity and get started on your book
name.html: Free your creativity and get started on your book

description.text:
An inspiring weekend workshop with writing coach and book editor Philippa Pride, who has worked with bestselling authors such as Stephen King.   
Learn how to overcome self-doubt, find your voice and become a more disciplined writer at this fantastic masterclass with Philippa Pride. Suitable for writers of all skill levels, the class will teach you workable techniques to help you to channel your inner creativity, even when inspiration is running dry.   
Over the course of the weekend, you’ll take part in practical workshops that will help you to plan, structure and pitch your book. With exercises tailored to the abilities and interests of students, it’s the ideal chance to get professional feedback in a supportive group environment. Book your place now – and learn how to spend less time worrying and more time enjoying the writing process. 
Course content  

Setting goals and a writing schedule to suit your life
Exercises for creativity – how to find your unique voice, switch off your inner critic and enjoy the writing process
How to shape your book and create ‘narrative drive’
How to create compelling plots, characters and dialogue
Visualisations – the magic of imagery and metaphor
Structuring your book – the benefits of a chapter breakdown
Moving from concept to final draft
Q&A, writing exercises and group discussion 

Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter, and read our latest articles and interviews on our blog. 
Tutor profile 
Philippa Pride has been running creative writing courses since 2006, combining her skills as a certified NLP master practitioner and coach with her inside knowledge of the publishing profession. Before setting up her own business, The Book Doctor, Philippa was a commissioning editor for Hodder. She continues her connection with Hodder as British editor for bestselling author Stephen King. 
Testimonials  

There was a really great energy in the room. The course attracted an interesting mix of people who were easy to engage with and Philippa set a positive tempo from the outset.
I found [Philippa] both an inspiration and a pleasure, and she made each and every one of us feel valued.
I thought the masterclass with Philippa was faultless. It exceeded my expectations in every way – in its content; structure; the professional way in which it was run; the friendliness of the Guardian staff; in the warm and very supportive atmosphere of the classroom and most of all in Philippa’s exceptional ability to teach, guide and inspire.

Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Data visualisation: A one-day workshop
name.html: Data visualisation: A one-day workshop

description.text:
Learn to use infographics to present complex information simply, elegantly and beautifully  
Whether you’re working on a presentation, a website or teaching materials, nothing tells a complex story faster than an infographic. This intensive one-day course gives you everything you need to create memorable static and interactive infographics – from how to find data and tailor it to your audience, to how to create maximum impact with your design. 
Led by Tobias Sturt and Adam Frost, formerly of the Guardian’s Digital Agency, now the directors of Graphic, a specialist data visualisation agency, the course delivers a series of lectures and workshops which give you the opportunity to get expert feedback on your work. Detailed hand-outs ensure this course offers a long-term benefit to your communications. 
Course content 

The importance of good visual storytelling
Designing and presenting graphs and charts to maximise their impact and memorability
How to find and analyse data, and match it to the needs of your audience
The evolution of data visualisation, and examples of best practice
How raw data can be turned into striking visual stories, including both flat graphic design (infographics) and interactives.
Two workshops in which participants collaborate and create their own visualisations before presenting them back to the group

Please note: Although we do discuss the different visualisation software options available, this is not a software training course 
This course is for you if... 

You have to present for a living, using Powerpoint, Prezi or similar software
You work with data and wish to learn more about turning data into something visually compelling
You’re a designer who wishes to learn more about information graphics
 You’re a developer who is interested in creating more usable and elegant front-end solutions
We also offer further bespoke Data Visualisation training for teams – click here for more information.

Tutor profiles 
Adam Frost was formerly head of Data visualisation at the Guardian’s Digital Agency. He is now content director at Graphic. His work has appeared on the Guardian, the New Statesman, Buzzfeed and elsewhere. He has produced infographics and interactives for a range of public and private-sector clients including the Department for Education, HMRC, Google, P&G, Nestle and Unilever. 
Tobias Sturt was head of Creative at the Guardian’s Digital Agency and is now creative director of Graphic, an agency specialising in data visualisation. He has been working in digital storytelling for almost two decades, in all kinds of media, from web to TV to games to infographics. He has also worked on more conventional digital development projects, from website design to branding, from mobile app interfaces to print projects.  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Copywriting: A two-day bootcamp
name.html: Copywriting: A two-day bootcamp

description.text:
Learn how to write commercial copy that's engaging and searchable at this in-depth weekend course  
We don’t normally condone the hard sell – but we can teach you how to make your readers an offer they can’t refuse. Whether you want to improve the quality of marketing or campaigning materials, or give your website a more professional edge, this in-depth copywriting course will make a real difference to your commercial writing skills. 
In the space of two days, copywriter and journalist Eddy Lawrence will teach you how to write persuasive copy for all purposes. You’ll learn how to target specific audiences in language they’ll relate to, and how to make a compelling story out of seemingly dry data. In addition, you’ll learn what SEO can (and can’t) do for you, as well as how to make your online copy easier for people to find. Don’t miss out on this fantastic masterclass – book your place now and learn how to write commercial copy that’s engaging and gets real results for your brand.  
Content  

Writing good copy for all purposes – from websites to product descriptions, press releases and newsletters 
The key differences between print and online copy
How to read your audience, and tailor your content to them
Finding stories in data, or relating your copy to existing news hooks
The essential components of copy – headlines, standfirsts, subheads, captions, furniture
Tone and language – how to establish a readable, memorable styleHow to make your copy searchable and findable through judicious keywording
The benefits of SEO (search engine optimisation)
Creating content to represent different brands
Practical exercises with opportunity for feedback on work carried out during the class
Q&A

 You may also be interested in… 

How to write better copy
Writing persuasive copy: A one-day bootcamp

Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter, and read our latest articles and interviews on our blog.  
  
Tutor profile 
  
Eddy Lawrence is a copywriter with over 20 years of writing and editing experience. He has written for and edited publications including The Face, Melody Maker and Jack, and even some that are still going, such as Time Out, NME, Shortlist and the Guardian. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Plot and character: A creative writing course with Adele Parks
name.html: Plot and character: A creative writing course with Adele Parks

description.text:
Learn how to bring your characters to life on the page, use plot devices to best effect and stay motivated as a writer at this workshop with bestselling novelist Adele Parks  
A novel is a marathon not a sprint. Writing one requires commitment and careful planning, no matter how much experience you have. If you’re thinking about writing a novel, or have started one and lost your way, this masterclass will help you to define your plot, subject and theme, and create truly compelling characters. 
Taught by bestselling novelist Adele Parks, this class will give novelists of all levels a new sense of creative direction and motivation. You’ll take part in practical writing exercises, and learn an arsenal of tricks and techniques that you can apply to your own novel.  
Content  

Understanding the differences between plot, subject and theme – and identifying them within your own novel 
Expert advice on how to structure your story – and make a clear plan for writing your novel 
How to really get to know your characters and find out what motivates them
Introducing your protagonist
Plot structure – how to maximise conflict, suspense, resolve and twists 
Key questions you should ask yourself as a writer  – and tips for how to stay motivated 
How to write – and re-write – your first sentence 
Q&A and practical exercises, with opportunity for feedback on work carried out during the class

Tutor profile 
Adele Parks has published 15 novels in 15 years, all of which have been bestsellers. Her books include Larger Than Life, Spare Brides and If You Go Away. In 2010, Adele was one of the judges for the Costa Book Awards. Find her on Twitter here.  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Food styling and photography with Rosie Reynolds and Jill Mead
name.html: Food styling and photography with Rosie Reynolds and Jill Mead

description.text:
Learn how to take mouth-watering pictures of food for your blog, menu or portfolio 
Whether you’re a photographer, blogger or aspiring food stylist, this masterclass will transform your ability to create stunning pictures of food. Led by Guardian Cook photographer Jill Mead and food stylist Rosie Reynolds, this highly interactive course covers the technical and creative essentials of food photography – from how to get the right lighting, to how to make good food look even better.  
The day includes a mixture of talks and workshops, and a photo-shoot where you’ll put your new skills to the test. Plus, you’ll receive guidance on breaking into the industry, as well as tips on how to work to a commercial brief. With plenty of practical exercises on your DSLR camera, the course is guaranteed to help you to create better images for your blog, menu or career portfolio. 
Course content 

A practical guide to the right lights, lens and camera
Lighting, angles, composition, framing and cropping images
How to analyse food colour, texture and characteristics
How food reacts to the environment – and how to control it
Food modelling for preparation and “hero shots”
How to develop your food styling skills
Tips on making real food look better
Hands-on test shoot – get involved in a practical food photography session during the class
What makes a strong image – the differing demands of editorial and commercial food photography
How to shoot on location (or borrow a photogenic kitchen)
Working with stylists, props and home economists
Working to a food shoot brief 
How to get into food styling: helpful shortcuts and qualifications
Q&A and discussion

This course is for you if… 

 You run or contribute to a food blog or website, and want to make it look more professional
You’re a budding food stylist or photographer, who wants to learn about the creative and technical aspects of the job
You’re a restaurateur who wants to take tempting pictures to illustrate your menu or PR materials

Course requirements 

PLEASE NOTE: This is an intermediate-level course. Attendees should be familiar with the basic manual settings of a DSLR camera.
Attendees should bring along their own digital SLR camera and be comfortable using it. They are also advised to bring along a personal laptop to upload their photographs. No software is necessary, just the means to upload and view photographs. A house computer will also be available during the course, as well spare card readers and plug sockets to charge laptops.

Tutor profiles  
Jill Mead is a photographer for the Guardian and Observer who regularly contributes to the Guardian’s Cook section. In addition, she has been commissioned to illustrate numerous publications including three books with Gordon Ramsay and, more recently, the Mumsnet family cookbook. 
Rosie Reynolds is a freelance food stylist, recipe writer and developer. After completing a diploma at Leiths School of Food and Wine in 2010, she started working for BBC Good Food and Olive magazine. More recently, Rosie has worked on book projects with Glynn Purnell, from Great British Menu, Franco Manca and Bill Granger, and is a regular contributor to Guardian Cook.  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Persiana: A Middle Eastern cookery masterclass with Sabrina Ghayour
name.html: Persiana: A Middle Eastern cookery masterclass with Sabrina Ghayour

description.text:
A unique opportunity for a small group of people to improve their cooking skills and spend the day with Sabrina Ghayour, author of multi-award-winning cookbook Persiana 
Celebrate the food of the Middle East at this exclusive cookery masterclass withSabrina Ghayour, author of multi-award-winning cookbook Persiana. During this hands-on course, you’ll learn how to create a spicy chicken stew, a variety of sumptuous garnishes and side dishes, and a decadent dessert, all bursting with flavours from the Southern and Eastern shores of the Mediterranean Sea. 
This class is a unique opportunity for a small group of people to soak up insights on the history of Persian cookery, and lots of practical cookery tips and ideas. After you’ve prepared your main dishes, you’ll sit down to a sumptuous meal with Sabrina, and have the chance to quiz her about her life as a cook and food writer, as well as her appearances on TV shows such as BBC Two’s Great British Menu. You’ll finish up by cooking a traditional Middle Eastern dessert that you can take home with you, and – if you’re feeling generous – share with your friends or family. 
Spaces are limited to 16 people so book your place now – you’ll be amazed what you can cook up in the space of a day… 
What you’ll cook… 

A delicious spicy chicken stew with apricots, preserved lemons and eggs
The perfect batch of basmati rice, full of flavour and texture
Smoked Afghan-style aubergines with fragrant herbs
A zingy apple, sumac, red onion and pomegranate salad
Tasty lamb, fennel and apricot lollipops
A decadent Middle Eastern cake that you can take home with you

What to bring 

Please bring along an apron and/or clothes that you don’t mind getting a bit messy, as well as some tupperware or containers

This class takes place at School of Wok, an award-winning cookery school in Covent Garden, central London 
More about your teacher… 
Sabrina Ghayour is an Iranian-born, self-taught cook, whose debut book Persiana: Recipes from the Middle East and beyond topped the bestseller lists and won Observer Food Monthly’s best new cookbook award in 2014. She also runs the hugely popular Sabrina’s Kitchen supper club in various locations across London, and has appeared on programmes including BBC One’s Saturday Kitchen and Gordon Ramsay’s F-Word, among others. In 2015, Sabrina was a guest judge on BBC 2’s Great British Menu. She tweets @SabrinaGhayour. 
  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Feature writing and digital storytelling with Jon Henley
name.html: Feature writing and digital storytelling with Jon Henley

description.text:
Senior Guardian feature writer Jon Henley reveals how to make the most of digital journalism 
Online reporting means the news now travels as fast as a story develops. This illuminating evening course, led by senior Guardian feature writer Jon Henley, explores the opportunities created by digital platforms, and how you can use them to tell powerful stories. Whether you’re new to journalism or want to update your digital skillset, the class is a fantastic opportunity to soak up insights from one of the Guardian’s most respected journalists. 
Using examples from the Guardian’s award-winning, multimedia reporting projects, the class shows you how to build flexibility into a story, allowing you to stay abreast of developments as they happen. You’ll also learn the fundamental storytelling principles that underpin all quality journalism, whether online or print, as well as the best ways to use social media to source stories and grab the attention of an online audience. 
Course content 

Why journalism in the digital age has to be different
How to use social media to source and tell stories
Why writing for the web changes the way journalists write
How to spot a good story
The fundamentals of good storytelling, in print and online
Multimedia storytelling – how to tell one story across several different platforms
Q&A

Tutor profile

description.html:
Senior Guardian feature writer Jon Henley reveals how to make the most of digital journalism

Online reporting means the news now travels as fast as a story develops. This illuminating evening course, led by senior Guardian feature writer Jon Henley, explores the opportunities created by digital platforms, and how you can use them to tell powerful stories. Whether you’re new to journalism or want to update your digital skillset, the class is a fantastic opportunity to soak up insights from one of the Guardian’s most respected journalists.

Using examples from the Guardian’s award-winning, multimedia reporting projects, the class shows you how to build flexibility into a story, allowing you to stay abreast of developments as they happen. You’ll also learn the fundamental storytelling principles that underpin all quality journalism, whether online or print, as well as the best ways to use social media to source stories and grab the attention of an online audience.

Course content

  • Why journalism in the digital age has to be different
  • How to use social media to source and tell stories
  • Why writing for the web changes the way journalists write
  • How to spot a good story
  • The fundamentals of good storytelling, in print and online
  • Multimedia storytelling – how to tell one story across several different platforms
  • Q&A

Tutor profile

name.text: Understanding climate change: An evening class with James Randerson
name.html: Understanding climate change: An evening class with James Randerson

description.text:
This timely class demystifies the science of climate change and discusses how humanity can get off fossil fuels – with James Randerson, the Guardian’s assistant national news editor  
It’s the most pressing issue of our time, but many of us feel we don’t fully understand climate change. This evening masterclass covers the key issues in the climate debate and demystifies the science behind it – from the meaning of ‘the greenhouse effect’ to the environmental benefits of renewable energy systems such as solar power.  
Led by James Randerson, the Guardian’s assistant national news editor, this timely class takes place following the historic Paris climate summit in December 2015, where almost 200 world nations agreed a deal that involves significant cuts in carbon pollution. There has never been a more important and exciting time to learn about the future of our planet – and in the spirit of the Guardian’s award-winning Keep it in the ground campaign, the tone of the class will be one of hope. 
More about your teacher… 
James Randerson is assistant national news editor at the Guardian, where he has a particular responsibility for environment, science and technology news. James was previously the paper’s science correspondent. He tweets @james_randerson.  
Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter, and read our latest articles and interviews on our blog. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Beginner's guide to social media for businesses
name.html: Beginner's guide to social media for businesses

description.text:
A foolproof introduction to online marketing, taught by Amy Hobson from social media consultancy SocialB 
Whether you run your own business, or want to use social media as part of your job, this course will demystify the three main social platforms: Twitter, Facebook and LinkedIn. Suitable for complete beginners, the class explains how to set up accounts, build a community and promote your business.  
Over the course of the day, you’ll also discover how to design a social media strategy for your brand. Plus, you’ll learn how to measure the impact of all those shares, likes and re-tweets. Book your place now – and learn how to master social media and grow your brand’s online presence.   
Content 

Why is social media so important for businesses?
How to set up accounts and create compelling content
Audience targeting and behaviours
How to integrate social media into your current marketing plan
Developing a successful social media strategy for your business
Measuring the effectiveness of your content
Reputation management – how to deal with negative comments
An overview of the most valuable social media tools available for businesses
Q&A

You may also be interested in...  

Advanced social media marketing for businesses
The beginner’s guide to creating a successful blog

Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter, and read our latest articles and interviews on our blog.  
Tutor profile   
Amy Hobson is a social media trainer for SocialB. Over the course of her career, she’s worked extensively within the franchising and retail sector for both national and international brands.

name.text: How to find your voice as a writer with Gary Younge
name.html: How to find your voice as a writer with Gary Younge

description.text:
A unique opportunity to learn from one of the Guardian’s most respected columnists 
They say you should dance like no one’s watching. Gary Younge, editor-at-large for the Guardian, thinks you should write in a similar frame of mind, giving full rein to your unique blend of references and values. During this inspirational masterclass, Gary will share his advice on how to develop your voice, structure a piece of writing and put forward a compelling argument. 
Whether you’re considering a career in journalism, or want to improve your writing skills, this is an unmissable opportunity to learn from one of the Guardian’s most respected writers. Tickets are limited so book your place now – and let Gary inspire you to find your true voice as a writer. 
Content 

Conveying your values and beliefs within your writing
Raising important issues in your work
Developing a strong and distinctive voice
One column, one argument – the importance of clarity and focus in column-writing
How to grab the reader’s attention, and make your writing accessible to as many people as possible
The mechanics of writing a column and structuring a piece
Anticipating counter-arguments – and addressing them in your writing
Q&A – a unique opportunity to pick the brains of one of the Guardian’s leading columnists

A percentage of tickets for this event have been donated to schemes which support greater diversity in the media. 
Tutor profile 
Gary Younge is the Guardian’s editor-at-large. He also writes a monthly column for the Nation magazine, and is the author of several books including The Speech: The Story Behind Martin Luther King’s Dream and No Place Like Home: A Black Briton’s Journey Through the American South. Read his Guardian articles here. 
You may also be interested in… 

Getting started as a journalist with Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
Writing opinion pieces with Polly Toynbee and Tim Dowling

Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter, and read our latest articles and interviews on our blog. 
Testimonials 

Gary was so personal, engaging and genuine. He needs to go on tour with this and make it into a one man show. Fabulous!!!
Well structured and great content. It was good to have the course structure outlined and to stick to that.
Gary did not disappoint - a totally engaging speaker, he gave us lots to think about and delivered it with humour and style.

Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: How to pitch your book to publishers
name.html: How to pitch your book to publishers

description.text:
Advice on how to get your novel or non-fiction book published – from book industry expert Scott Pack 
  
Have you always dreamed of getting a book published? Whether you’re writing fiction or non-fiction, this class with publisher Scott Pack offers straight-talking advice on how to ensure your submission gets noticed by editors. You’ll learn everything from how to identify the right publisher or agent, to how to write a killer synopsis and cover letter. 
  
Plus, for those brave enough to share their pitches, he’ll be looking for volunteers to submit their work for live feedback during the class. If you’re ready (or almost ready) to pitch your book to a publisher, you won’t regret investing in this course. 
  
Course content 
  

How to write a cover letter that will ensure your pitch and synopsis get read by an editor
The secrets to writing a good synopsis
Fiction v non-fiction
Putting together an enticing submission package for a novel or non-fiction book
Researching possible agents and publishers – and identifying the right ones for your work
Common mistakes made by writers – and how to avoid them
Practical session – a few volunteers are selected to have their pitch critiqued during the class
Q&A – an invaluable opportunity to pick the brains of a highly experienced publisher

  
Pre-course preparation 
  

If you would like to bring along a copy of your cover letter and/or pitch, Scott will be looking for volunteers on the night to submit their work for live feedback. Please note that this is not compulsory and only a select few submissions will be reviewed during the class

  
Tutor profile 
  
Scott Pack has worked in the book industry for fifteen years. He was head of buying for Waterstones before becoming a publisher and running the Friday Project imprint at HarperCollins. Scott is currently associate editor at Unbound, the world’s first crowdfunding publisher. He tweets @meandmybigmouth. 
  
  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Classics: Exploring Homer's Iliad and the Odyssey
name.html: Classics: Exploring Homer's Iliad and the Odyssey

description.text:
Back to school: A brand new series of evening classes on the subjects you used to learn, taught by the teachers you wish you’d had 
Although the origins of the Iliad and the Odyssey are wrapped in mystery, their influence continues to reverberate throughout Western culture. This masterclass with Charlotte Higgins is a fantastic opportunity to learn about Homer’s two great epics and the immeasurable influence they’ve had on theatre, poetry, novels and cinema. 
The Iliad and the Odyssey are among the oldest extant works of Western literature, usually dated to around the eight century BC. During this class, you’ll examine the poetics, imagery and structure of these two dramatic tales, set during and after the Trojan War. You’ll learn how they informed subsequent Greek literature – including the great Greek tragedies and the lyric outpourings of Sappho, one of the few known female poets of the ancient world. Plus, you’ll discover how Homer’s work continues to inspire writing in the present day, from Michael Longley to Alice Oswald and Margaret Atwood. 
Charlotte is one of the UK’s best-known writers and classicists. She’s the Guardian’s chief culture writer and has written numerous books including It’s All Greek to Me, which brings the history of ancient Greece to life. If you wish you’d studied the Classics at school, or want to reignite your passion for the subject, don’t miss out on this fascinating masterclass. Book your place now and let Charlotte reawaken your interest in the ancient world – and the ways it continues to inform the present. 
More about your teacher... 
Charlotte Higgins is the chief culture writer of the Guardian and a member of its editorial board. A classicist by education, she has written three books on aspects of the ancient world. The most recent, Under Another Sky: Journeys in Roman Britain, was shortlisted for the Samuel Johnson prize for non-fiction. This New Noise, a book based on her nine-part series of essays on the BBC, was published by Guardian-Faber in 2015. 
Back to school is a new range of evening classes covering the subjects you once enjoyed, or always wanted to learn. Browse the full range here. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Infographics for beginners
name.html: Infographics for beginners

description.text:
Discover how to create beautiful infographics from scratch at this hands-on masterclass with data visualisation expert Andy Pemberton 
If you work with statistics, evidence or information, infographics are a fantastic way to present complex data in an engaging way. During this hands-on masterclass with data visualisation expert Andy Pemberton, you’ll use your own data to identify a story, craft a compelling structure for your infographic, and write a persuasive headline. Suitable for beginners, the class will give you the tools and confidence to create your own data visualisations, whether you want to improve your presentations, or just create something beautiful.  Content 

Reading and identifying stories in datasets
The importance of relevance, timeliness and exclusivity
The science behind great infographics – including the ‘five-act structure’ 
How to develop stories and emotion through infographics, online and offline 
Writing searchable headlines and persuasive ‘calls to action’ 
Practical exercises – students break into small groups to create their own infographics using data they’ve brought to the class 
Q&A and opportunity for feedback on work carried out during the class

Please note this is not a design course – practical exercises will be carried out on pen and paper  What to bring  

You’re invited to bring along data you’re currently working on, which you’ll use during practical exercises

  
Tutor profile Andy Pemberton is a leading data visualisation and content expert who has worked with the United Nations, Cisco, Aviva and many other international brands. He’s currently working on a book, website and set of infographics called What’s Next for Banks. 
 Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Column-writing: A masterclass with Lucy Mangan and Owen Jones
name.html: Column-writing: A masterclass with Lucy Mangan and Owen Jones

description.text:
Learn how to present a strong argument with confidence at this masterclass with some of the Guardian’s leading journalists   
A well-written column is an effective way to raise important issues and express a strong opinion. Whatever your point of view, this masterclass will help you to turn your thoughts and knowledge into a persuasive piece of writing. 
Suitable for writers of all levels, this entertaining day of talks includes advice on everything from coming up with ideas to structuring a column. The class is also a unique opportunity to pick the brains of some of the Guardian’s leading journalists at our offices in London. 
Content 

Owen Jones, Guardian columnist and bestselling author of The Establishment, offers tips on getting started as a journalist, finding a specialism and developing your writing voice
Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee gives advice on how to write a column and raise important issues through your writing
Guardian Weekend columnist Tim Dowling shares tips on how to use your own life experiences in your writing
Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff offers guidance on how to be more persuasive and build an argument in your writing
An exclusive Q&A with Guardian writer Lucy Mangan, where she discusses her writing and offers guidance on finding sources of inspiration for a column

Speaker profiles 
Polly Toynbee is a columnist for the Guardian and former BBC social affairs editor. She won the Orwell Prize for journalism in 1998 and in 2007 was named Columnist of the Year at the British Press Awards. She has also written and co-authored many books including her latest, Cameron’s Coup. She tweets@pollytoynbee. 
Lucy Mangan is a writer for the Guardian and columnist for Stylist magazine. She’s also the author of five books including The Reluctant Brideand Hopscotch & Handbags: The Truth about Being a Girl. She tweets@LucyMangan. 
Owen Jones is a columnist at the Guardian and a former columnist at the Independent, as well as a regular TV/radio broadcaster and public speaker. He’s the author of Chavs, The Establishment: And How They Get Away With It and the soon-to-be-released The Politics of Hope. Owen is the winner of the 2012 Stonewall Journalist of the Year and 2013 Political Book Awards Young Writer of the Year. He tweets@OwenJones84. 
Gaby Hinsliff is a Guardian columnist and writer, as well as a political columnist for The Pool. She was previously political editor of the Observer, and has been a judge for the Orwell Prize for Blogs. Gaby is also the author of Half a Wife. She tweets @gabyhinsliff. 
Tim Dowling is a journalist for the Guardian. He writes a weekly column for Weekend magazine and is the author of several books, including How To Be A Husband. Read Tim’s Guardian articles here. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

He’s the author of Chavs, The Establishment: And How They Get Away With It and the soon-to-be-released The Politics of Hope. Owen is the winner of the 2012 Stonewall Journalist of the Year and 2013 Political Book Awards Young Writer of the Year. He tweets@OwenJones84.

Gaby Hinsliff is a Guardian columnist and writer, as well as a political columnist for The Pool. She was previously political editor of the Observer, and has been a judge for the Orwell Prize for Blogs. Gaby is also the author of Half a Wife. She tweets @gabyhinsliff.

Tim Dowling is a journalist for the Guardian. He writes a weekly column for Weekend magazine and is the author of several books, including How To Be A Husband. Read Tim’s Guardian articles here.

name.text: Creating miniature worlds: Short story writing with Ross Raisin
name.html: Creating miniature worlds: Short story writing with Ross Raisin

description.text:
During this fun writing workshop, you’ll improve your technical skills and create two pieces of short fiction to be proud of - with Ross Raisin, award-winning author of God’s Own Country  
What are the key elements of a great short story? How do you make a story captivating and satisfying for people to read? This masterclass with award-winning author Ross Raisin will reveal the secrets of writing standout short stories, all in the space of a day. 
Whether you’re new to writing or want to improve your skills, this class will teach you how to create compelling characters, dialogue and storylines. By the end of the day, you’ll have completed two pieces of short fiction – a story and a piece of flash fiction – and have the skills and confidence to continue writing stories after the class. 
Content 

The particular nature of the short story
The short story’s relationship to the novel – and whether the process of writing one is different to the other
Analysis and discussion of extracted contemporary short fiction (provided during the class)
Technical workshops on the key aspects of fiction writing – from character to dialogue and language
Practical exercises – write your own piece of flash fiction and your own short story during the class
Opportunities for feedback in a supportive and encouraging environment
Q&A and group discussion

What to bring 

Please bring along a collection of short stories or a single story that you particularly like. You’ll be encouraged to let the group know about it, therefore helping each other to widen your knowledge of different short stories and writers

Tutor profile 
Ross Raisin was named one of Granta’s Best of Young British Novelists in 2013. He’s written short stories for Esquire, BBC Radio Three and Granta, among others, and has contributed to anthologies including Best British Short Stories. He’s published two novels: Waterline (2011) and God’s Own Country (2008), for which he won awards including The Sunday Times Young Writer of the Year and a Betty Trask Award. Ross teaches creative writing at Goldsmiths University and as part of the UEA-Guardian Masterclasses programme. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Lifehacks: How to lead a happier, healthier life
name.html: Lifehacks: How to lead a happier, healthier life

description.text:
Discover how to improve your diet, manage your time more effectively and save money at this masterclass with certified life coaches, doctors and food nutritionists 
Ever feel overwhelmed by to-do lists? Struggle to find the time to eat healthily, manage your finances or rid your home of clutter? This masterclass will teach you workable strategies to take control of your life and focus on what really matters. 
This inspiring day of talks brings together certified coaches, doctors and food nutritionists to help you manage your time more effectively, dial down stress, and lead a healthier and more fulfilling life. 
The price of your ticket includes a copy of Amelia Freer’s bestselling book Cook. Nourish. Glow 
Content 

Qualified nutritional therapist Amelia Freer gives expert advice on how to improve your relationship with food, and how small changes to your diet can make a big difference to your health
Life coach Fiona Buckland shares professional advice on how to improve your relationship with sleep, rest and your waking hours, enabling you to achieve your goals without burning out
John and Irma Mustoe, co-authors of The Penny Pincher’s Book, give expert advice on living better for less - from how to save money and cut down on waste, to how to shop more intelligently
Vanessa King, a leading expert on the practical application of the science of happiness, offers evidence-based advice on how to live a happier, more fulfilling life
Life coach Juliet Landau-Pope offers guidance on how to declutter your home, manage your schedule and prioritise what really matters
Samantha Clarke, a happiness consultant and changemaker, offers guidance on how to build better relationships at home and be more successful in the workplace

Speaker profiles 
Amelia Freer is a qualified nutritional therapist and author of two bestselling books, Cook. Nourish. Glow and Eat. Nourish. Glow. Among her success stories are famous names such as Boy George, James Corden and Sam Smith. She tweets@AmeliaFreer. 
Fiona Buckland is a life coach, facilitator and writer. She’s trained by the internationally recognised Coaches Training Institute and is a member of the International Coach Federation. Fiona is passionate about supporting people to unleash their potential by switching off autopilot, and learning how to a live richer, fuller life. She tweets @lifework_coach. 
Juliet Landau-Pope is a certified coach, professional organiser and study skills expert, with a particular interest in decluttering. Through her work, she motivates people to manage their time and space more effectively. She tweets@jlpcoach. 
John and Irma Mustoe are the co-authors of The Penny Pincher’s Book and The Penny Pincher’s Book Revisited, both subtitled Living Better for Less. The books followed six years of publishing the Penny Pincher Paper, which shared tips on how to enjoy an abundant life on a limited income. Read their article for the Guardian here. 
Samantha Clarke is a happiness consultant and changemaker who specialises in helping companies develop innovative ways to shape culture, relationships and work processes. She tweets @samanthaand_. 
Vanessa King is a leading expert in positive psychology, resilience and wellbeing. She has particular expertise in the practical application of the science of happiness. Vanessa is a board member and consultant for Action for Happiness, the UK-based not-for-profit organisation. She tweets @changespace. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: How to write a children's book: A masterclass with Philip Ardagh and Cressida Cowell
name.html: How to write a children's book: A masterclass with Philip Ardagh and Cressida Cowell

description.text:
Join some of the most respected names in children’s writing and publishing for this fun-filled day of talks - speakers include Philip Ardagh, winner of the Roald Dahl Funny prize, and Cressida Cowell, author of the hugely popular series How To Train Your Dragon 
If you’ve always wanted to write for children, or want to improve your craft, don’t miss out on this incredible day of talks with some of the UK’s leading authors and publishers.  
Hosted by children’s fiction author Laura Dockrill, the day includes expert advice from Philip Ardagh, author of The Grunts and winner of the Roald Dahl Funny prize, and Barry Cunningham, a publisher best known for signing up a little-known author called J. K. Rowling during his time at Bloomsbury.  
Over the course of the day, you’ll soak up tips on everything from how to develop your own distinctive writing style to how to write for different age groups and - importantly - have fun while doing it. With sessions from award-winning teen writer Juno Dawson and Cressida Cowell, author of the hugely popular series How To Train Your Dragon, it’s the ultimate masterclass for anyone who wants to learn how to keep a young audience entertained by their storytelling. 
Content 

Philip Ardagh, winner of the Roald Dahl Funny prize, discusses his love of children’s literature and gives advice on the challenges of “writing funny”, using his legendary humour, panache… and beard
Publisher Barry Cunningham, who has worked with bestselling authors including J. K. Rowling and Spike Milligan, offers expert tips on how to get your writing into print 
Children’s writer Laura Dockrill, author of the much-loved Darcy Burdock books, shares advice on how to unlock creativity, find your “inner child” and develop a distinctive writing voice 
Juno Dawson, multi-award-winning author of teen thrillers such as Hollow Pike, offers guidance on the key differences between children’s, “middle-grade” and young adult writing 
Author-illustrator Cressida Cowell, whose works include the popular How To Train Your Dragon series, gives tips on how to write a series of books – plus how you can draw upon feedback from children to inform your writing 

 You’ll have the opportunity to purchase books by all authors at a discounted price on the day 
Host profile 
Laura Dockrill is a writer, illustrator and performance poet whose work includes Lorali and the acclaimed Darcy Burdock books for children. In addition to her work as a writer and creative writing tutor, she’s been a roaming reporter for the Roald Dahl Funny Prize and performed her work on Newsnight, BBC Breakfast and BBC Woman’s Hour. She tweets @LauraDockrill. 
Speaker profiles 
Philip Ardagh is the author of over 100 books, including Grubtown Tales and The Grunts. He has won the prestigious Roald Dahl Funny Prize, and is an instantly recognisable figure at literary festivals around the world due to his ridiculously big, bushy beard and size sixteen feet. He reviews children’s books for the Guardian and is currently developing a series for television. He tweets @PhilipArdagh. 
Cressida Cowell has written and illustrated twelve books in the popular How to Train Your Dragon series, which has sold over seven million copies worldwide and is published in 37 languages. The series was turned into an award-winning Dreamworks film series of the same name, as well as a TV series shown on Netflix. Cressida’s other works include the Emily Brown series, and she has been the recipient of the Nestle Children’s Book Prize. She’s been a proud ambassador for the National Literacy Trust for almost ten years. She tweets @CressidaCowell. 
Barry Cunningham is one of the most respected names in publishing, having worked with all the great names in children’s books including Roald Dahl and Spike Milligan. During his time at Puffin, he was responsible for the re-launch of Beatrix Potter, and at Bloomsbury he signed up J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone. In 2000, Barry decided to start his own publishing company and the result was Chicken House, a lively and creative company publishing original children’s books, with a special emphasis on new fiction. In 2010, Barry received an OBE in recognition of his contribution to children’s literature.He tweets @BarryChicken. 
Juno Dawson - formerly known as James - is the multi-award-winning author of dark teen thrillers including Hollow Pike, Cruel Summer and Under My Skin. In 2015, she released her first contemporary romance All of the Above, and this year she’ll launch a new non-fiction title, Mind Your Head, which covers everything a young person needs to know about mental health. This year, Juno will also author one of the World Book Day titles, Spot the Difference. She tweets @junodawson.  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: How to use Instagram to build your brand
name.html: How to use Instagram to build your brand

description.text:
Learn how to use this increasingly popular photo-sharing app to benefit your business 
  
Instagram is a fantastic way to build your brand’s online presence. During this three-hour masterclass with social media consultant Julie Falconer, you’ll learn why the most successful brands are incorporating images into their marketing strategies – and how you can use Instagram to increase your own following. 
  
The course covers the key elements of great Instagram images, and offers in-depth advice on how to engage with customers and build communities around your brand. Plus, you’ll get involved in fun practical exercises on your smartphone or tablet, where you’ll learn how to make your content stand out from the crowd.  
Course content 

How can Instagram benefit your business or brand?
Creating a compelling profile
The key elements of good Instagram photography
Growing your presence on Instagram – including using hashtags and @ mentions to best effect
Tips for using Instagram to engage with new and existing customers
How to build communities around your brand
Using Instagram to achieve goals for your business or personal brand
How to monitor the impact and success of your content
Practical exercises: use your smartphone or tablet to create and edit images during the class
Q&A and group discussion

This course is for you if… 

You have a business or personal brand you’d like to grow through Instagram
You work in marketing or PR and want to improve your ability to use Instagram as part of your job

Course requirements 

Attendees should be familiar with the basics of Instagram and have an account they can log into during the class
In order to take part in practical exercises, attendees should bring along a smartphone or tablet (and charger) with the Instagram app installed

Tutor profile 
Julie Falconer is a London-based writer and consultant. She runs the award-winning blog A Lady in London, for which she has developed a strong social media presence on Instagram. She has been listed as a top 20 travel Instagrammer by Esquire and Harper’s Bazaar, and Instagram has highlighted her as a suggested user. Julie teaches and lectures about blogging and social media in London and throughout the world.  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Visual social media for businesses: From Snapchat to Periscope
name.html: Visual social media for businesses: From Snapchat to Periscope

description.text:
A lively evening lecture covering the latest features in visual social media marketing - and how you can use them to get results for your business  
 Visual social media platforms are a great way to market your brand and reach new audiences. From Instagram and Facebook to Snapchat and Periscope, this evening class covers the key things you need to know about visual social media marketing. Plus, you’ll receive expert tips on using video and visual content to achieve results for your own business. 
Led by marketing expert Ed Goodman, this three-hour lecture is ideal for business owners and entrepreneurs looking to take advantage of new digital platforms. You’ll leave with the confidence to start or improve your visual social media strategy, and lots of ideas for creative content to share with your audience. 
Content 

How to create a realistic and successful social media strategy for your business
An overview of the major visual social media platforms: Instagram, Facebook, Periscope and Snapchat
Developing creative visual marketing content
Reaching target audiences and attracting followers
Maximising engagement – and going viral
Measuring your success and knowing your competitors
Brand and reputation management, including legal procedures
Case studies of social media campaigns that got results
Q&A

Please note: this evening lecture is not suitable for beginner’s to social media. For an introductory workshop, please see our Beginner’s guide to social media for businesses 
Speaker profile 
Ed Goodman is a start-up coach and a social media trainer for SocialB. He has a real passion for mentoring and training start-ups and small businesses to help achieve their goals – over 10,000 have benefited from Ed’s knowledge to date. He is also the co-author of New Business: Next Steps, a guide to managing, marketing and growing small businesses.   
  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Understanding the US election: An evening class with Gary Younge
name.html: Understanding the US election: An evening class with Gary Younge

description.text:
A fascinating evening class with Gary Younge, the Guardian’s editor-at-large, that will improve your understanding of US politics and the key presidential candidates – from Democrats such as Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, to Republican hopefuls such as Ted Cruz and Mitt Romney  
There’s no doubt about it – this is one of the most exciting US elections in history. It’s also one of the most complex. With 14 Republican candidates and three Democrats in line for the presidency, it can be difficult to keep track of it all. 
During this evening masterclass, the Guardian’s editor-at-large, Gary Younge, will discuss the key things you need to know about the upcoming election. You’ll receive an overview of the electoral landscape and the key issues at stake. Plus, you’ll deepen your understanding of the key candidates in the race – from Democrats such as Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, to Republican hopefuls such as Ted Cruz and Donald Trump.  
At the time of the masterclass, Gary will have just returned to the UK after reporting on the US primaries for a month. Don’t miss out on an incredible learning experience at the Guardian, book your place now and spend the evening learning how things are likely to play out in November 2016 – and why.  
More about your teacher…  
Gary Younge is the Guardian’s editor-at-large, and an award-winning journalist who has covered US politics for 12 years. He also writes a monthly column for the Nation magazine, and is the author of several books including The Speech: The Story Behind Martin Luther King’s Dream and Who Are We – And Should It Matter in the 21st Century?. Read Gary’s Guardian articles here. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

Plus, you’ll deepen your understanding of the key candidates in the race – from Democrats such as Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, to Republican hopefuls such as Ted Cruz and Donald Trump. 

At the time of the masterclass, Gary will have just returned to the UK after reporting on the US primaries for a month. Don’t miss out on an incredible learning experience at the Guardian, book your place now and spend the evening learning how things are likely to play out in November 2016 – and why. 

More about your teacher… 

Gary Younge is the Guardian’s editor-at-large, and an award-winning journalist who has covered US politics for 12 years. He also writes a monthly column for the Nation magazine, and is the author of several books including The Speech: The Story Behind Martin Luther King’s Dream and Who Are We – And Should It Matter in the 21st Century?. Read Gary’s Guardian articles here.

name.text: How to launch a pop-up shop
name.html: How to launch a pop-up shop

description.text:
Expert advice on the practicalities of pop-up retail, plus tips on how to bring your own brand to life on the high street  
Pop-up shops come in many shapes and sizes – from standalone kiosks and stalls, to spaces within existing shops. If you’ve got an idea for a pop-up venture, or want to move your online business into a physical retail space, this masterclass will help you to achieve your goals. 
Led by creative business expert Abigail Freeman, this evening class includes practical guidance on how to find and rent space, plus insider knowledge on the costs and challenges of pop-up retail. You’ll also receive tips on how to devise a pop-up concept that suits your own business objectives, as well as advice on how to ensure your pop-up stays up. 
Content 

An overview of pop-up retail and shop sharing
Where to start – objectives, concept, budget, location, timings and more
What to expect – benefits, challenges, costs and opportunities
How to get a new pop-up venture onto the high street
Advice on how to find and rent space in existing shops
Tips on moving an online business into a physical retail space
Business planning – how to create objectives for your own pop-up venture
Q&A and practical exercises

Tutor profile 
Abigail Freeman is a creative business expert, and director of marketing and partnerships for We Are Pop Up, a leading marketplace for short-term retail. She has previously worked with clients including University of the Arts London and the UK’s innovation agency, Nesta. Abigail is also a mentor at UCL’s MSc in technology entrepreneurship. She tweets @abigailfrmn.

name.text: Self-editing skills for novelists
name.html: Self-editing skills for novelists

description.text:
Learn how to think like an editor, polish your manuscript and bring out the strengths in your novel at this fantastic course with writing coach Roz Morris 
The most important work on a novel is done during the editing stage, where plots are sharpened, characters fleshed out and language refined. This interactive course with Roz Morris will help you to think like an editor and assess your own writing more critically. You’ll learn the most important skills of the editor’s job, and finish the day with an arsenal of techniques to help you turn your first draft into a polished manuscript. 
Course description 

Essential editing skills for authors
The creative approach to self-editing – how to make it more than just reworking your sentences
Polishing your style – tips and suggestions to keep a consistent voice
Mapping your weak spots – identifying particular issues and problems with your manuscript
How to improve structure and characters
Using themes to maintain coherence and create a slick, satisfying experience for the reader
How to decide if an abandoned book has potential – and how to get it started again
Q&A and group discussion

Tutor profile 
Roz Morris is a writer, fiction editor, journalist and the author of the Nail Your Novel series for writers. Her fiction has sold more than four million copies worldwide. Roz has worked as a writers’ mentor for Cornerstones Literary Consultancy. Find out more on her website.  
You may also be interested in… 

How to turn your idea into a novel with Jill Dawson
How to plan your novel and enjoy the novel writing process 

Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter, and read our latest articles and interviews on our blog.

name.text: How to improve your novel: A one-day workshop with Charlotte Mendelson
name.html: How to improve your novel: A one-day workshop with Charlotte Mendelson

description.text:
An in-depth workshop that will help you to build upon the strengths of your novel – and give it the best possible chance of being accepted by an agent 
Learn how to make your novel the best it can possibly be at this interactive course with Charlotte Mendelson, winner of the Somerset Maugham Award and the John Llewellyn Rhys Prize. Combining her experience as a novelist with twenty years’ experience as a publisher, Charlotte will help you to rigorously edit your work so it has the strongest possible chance of being accepted by an agent. 
This highly practical course is suitable for committed writers who are least half-way through a full-length work of fiction. Ahead of the course, you’ll need to submit a synopsis of your novel and an outline of any particular concerns (1,000 words max), both of which will be workshopped during the class. Don’t miss out on the chance to learn from one of the UK’s most respected and talented novelists – book your place now and make a commitment to improving your craft. 
 Content 

Writing and editing techniques to help you improve your novel
Interactive workshopping sessions using attendees’ synopses
Invaluable tips on how to avoid the ‘slush pile’ – and get your work accepted by agents and publishers
Overcoming structural problems with your novel, as well as common mistakes with plot, character, point-of-view and setting
Lessons from Charlotte’s career – what she’s learned as a writer vs what she’s learned as an editor
Q&A and group discussion

Course preparation  

Ahead of the course, attendees are required to submit a synopsis and a short outline of any specific concerns they’re experiencing with their novel. These documents combined should be no more than 1,000 words in length
Attendees are also welcome to submit a sample of prose from their novel if they wish (no more than 500 words), although this is not essential
Please email your synopsis and list of concerns to masterclasses.support@theguardian.com by 4pm on Friday 18th March. Or, if you sign up after this date, as soon as you can after you have bought your ticket

Tutor profile  
Charlotte Mendelson is an award-winning author whose latest novel, Almost English, was longlisted for the Man Booker Prize 2013 and the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction 2014. Her third novel, When We Were Bad, was shortlisted for the Orange Prize for Fiction. Other books include Daughters of Jerusalem, which won both the Somerset Maugham Award and the John Llewellyn Rhys Prize. In addition to her work as a novelist, Charlotte has twenty years’ experience working in publishing as a fiction editor. She tweets @CharlotteMende1.  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: How to create a successful app
name.html: How to create a successful app

description.text:
Soak up expert advice on how to generate ideas for mobile apps and work with developers at this fun evening lecture with Hannah Tempest, creative director of Mubaloo 
This evening seminar covers the key things you need to know to launch a successful app. Led by Hannah Tempest, creative director of one of the UK’s leading mobile consultancies, Mubaloo, the course includes advice on how to generate ideas for easy-to-use mobile apps, as well as how to approach developers and agencies to create your product. 
Course content 

An introduction to apps
Identifying clear objectives for a mobile project
The importance of user-centred design processes
Definition exercises – mapping commercial objectives and user experiences
Understanding user needs
How to approach persona profiling
T-bar exercise to analyse the ‘stickability’ factor of apps
Feature prioritisation and mobile roadmap development
The need for prototyping and Lean UX
How to put together a body of work for a developer or agency to create your app
Summary on the app delivery process and iterative building
Q&A

This course is for you if… 

You’re looking to create an app within your business
You work for a company or organisation who wants to develop a new app
You want to create and generate new ideas for mobile apps

Course preparation 

Attendees should bring along a smartphone and/or tablet with some apps previously installed
Attendees are encouraged to keep note of a few apps they have used the day before the course, with thoughts on what works and what doesn’t

Tutor profile 
Hannah Tempest is the creative director of Mubaloo, the UK’s leading mobile consultancy. At Mubaloo, she has worked on apps for clients including Bang & Olufsen, Haymarket and Aviva. Hannah has over 12 years’ experience in design and UX covering C2B and B2B in a wide variety of industries. She regularly runs workshops for businesses focused around digital and app design, and has spoken at events including TalkUX, Ladies that UX, Mobile Monday Bristol and SWUX. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: How to blend fact and fiction: A creative writing class with Lionel Shriver
name.html: How to blend fact and fiction: A creative writing class with Lionel Shriver

description.text:
The first in a series of exclusive writing classes curated by Lionel Shriver, the internationally bestselling author of We Need to Talk About Kevin  Learn how to write stories based on real-world issues at this incredible masterclass with Lionel Shriver, the virtuoso of topical fiction. Best known for her international bestseller We Need to Talk About Kevin, winner of the Orange Prize for Fiction in 2005, Lionel has researched and written stories exploring everything from the US healthcare system to obesity and terrorism. 
 During this evening class, you’ll get exclusive insights into how Lionel plots her novels, from first inspiration to the final page. Plus, you’ll receive expert advice that you can apply to your own work, including how to research non-fiction content and artfully weave fact and fiction in your writing.  
 Writing month with Lionel Shriver 
 This is the first in a series of writing classes specially curated by Lionel Shriver for the month of April. Keep an eye on our website or sign up to the Guardian Masterclasses newsletter to be the first to hear about more classes in this exclusive series, taught by some of the UK’s finest writers and editors.  Class preparation  You’re encouraged to arrive at the class with your idea for a fictional story or novel based on real-life events, along with a question for Lionel  Please note this preparation is not essential to attend the class, or benefit from it   More about your teacher…  Lionel Shriver is the author of eleven novels including So Much For That and The Post-Birthday World. Her international bestseller We Need to Talk About Kevin was awarded the prestigious Orange Prize For Fiction in 2005, and was later adapted into an award-winning feature film by Lynne Ramsay. Lionel’s twelfth novel, The Mandibles: A family 2027-2049, is published in May 2016 by The Borough Press, HarperFiction’s literary fiction imprint. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Social media for retailers
name.html: Social media for retailers

description.text:
Social media is no longer just for networking. Today, social platforms are an increasingly influential driver of consumer behavior. If you want to ensure your products reach the right people, don’t miss out on this fun and informative masterclass with social media trainer Amy Hobson. 
In the space of just three hours, you’ll learn the key things retailers need to know about Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest. Plus you’ll receive advice on everything from developing a social strategy to creating viral content. Book your place now and learn how social media can help you to build relationships, boost engagement and drive revenue. 
This masterclass is run in partnership with award-winning events and trade exhibitions company i2i. Find out more about i2i on their website. 
Course content 
- Coming up with creative marketing content for retail 
- Targeting different audiences and influencing consumer behavior 
- Maximising engagement – with advice on going viral 
- ‘Piggybacking’ on existing viral trends 
- Using social media to drive sales and revenue 
- What every retail business needs to know about Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest 
- Developing a realistic and successful social media strategy for your own business 
- Using planning and analytic tools to achieve your goals and measure success 
- Brand reputation and management 
- Q&A 
This course is for you if… 
- You’re a business owner who wants to learn how to build your brand through social media 
- You work for a small, medium or large retail business and want to discover new ways of engaging with customers 
- You’re a marketer looking to update your social media knowledge and skills 
Please note: Attendees should have a basic knowledge of one or more of the following social media platforms: Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest. 
What to bring 
- Attendees are invited to bring along a smartphone or tablet computer with Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest already set up – but this is not essential 
Sign up to our newsletter and you’ll be among the first to find out about our latest courses and special offers. You can also follow us on Twitter here. 
Tutor profile 
Amy Hobson is a social media trainer for SocialB. During her career, she’s worked extensively within the franchising and retail sector for both national and international brands. Amy is passionate about sharing her knowledge to assist growth and development within the retail industry. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Politics: The definitive guide to the British political system
name.html: Politics: The definitive guide to the British political system

description.text:
If you've always been interested in politics, don't miss out on this fascinating evening class with Guardian political writer and columnist John Harris 
British politics is more unpredictable now than it has been for decades. Following the recent “surprise” election result, debates have become increasingly complex – and increasingly fascinating. This lively politics masterclass with Guardian columnist John Harris will demystify Britain’s current climate, including the impact of the 2015 election result and declining political certainty.  If you were interested in politics at school, this is the ideal chance to reignite your passion for the subject. In the space of just two hours, you’ll receive an up-to-date politics lesson, and get involved in discussions on everything from the demise of “two-party politics” to the rise of national parties such as the SNP and UKIP. 
John is one of the Guardian’s leading columnists and the co-creator of the series Anywhere but Westminster, which explores politics outside the Westminster bubble. Don’t miss out on the chance to learn from one of our most experienced and committed political writers and let John reawaken your interest in current affairs and the future of UK politics. 
More about your teacher... 
John Harris is a political writer and columnist for the Guardian. He is also the co-creator, with John Domokos, of the video series Anywhere but Westminster. In addition to his work for the Guardian, John has written on politics, popular culture and music for publications including the New Statesman and Rolling Stone. His books include The Last Party and So Now Who Do We Vote For? Read John’s Guardian articles here. 
Back to school is a new range of evening classes covering the subjects you once enjoyed, or always wanted to learn. Browse the full range here.

name.text: How to find a literary agent with Juliet Mushens
name.html: How to find a literary agent with Juliet Mushens

description.text:
An unmissable masterclass with leading literary agent Juliet Mushens, including guest sessions from novelists Peter Newman and Ross Armstrong 
If you’re a new writer, the process of getting your book into print might seem a bit daunting. This unique masterclass with leading literary agent Juliet Mushens will demystify the publishing process and reveal what agents look for in fiction submissions. 
In the space of three hours, you’ll learn everything from how to prepare the perfect submissions package to how to edit your manuscript and pitch your novel to an agent. On the evening, Juliet will be joined by two of her most exciting authors, Peter Newman, whose works include the popular fantasy novel The Vagrant, and debut novelist Ross Armstrong, whose psychological thriller The Watcher will be published in January next year. 
Content 

What is a literary agent – what do they do and why do you need one?
How to research potential agents and decide who might be the best person to represent you
What do agents look for in submissions?
How to write a killer cover letter and synopsis
Expert advice on editing your manuscript
Advice on pitching your book to agents – and giving it the best possible change of being accepted
Discussion of pitches and blurbs for famous books
Practical session – selected attendees volunteer to read aloud a short blurb for their book, with opportunity for feedback on the evening (see below for more info)
Q&A with Juliet and her guest speaker

Class preparation 

You’re invited to bring along a short blurb or ‘elevator pitch’ for your book, if you wish to do so. The blurb should be similar in style to the copy on the back cover of books in shops – and no more than one paragraph in length
Juliet will ask between two and five volunteers to share their blurb with the group, with opportunity for feedback on the evening

Tutor profile 
Juliet Mushens is a literary agent whose authors range from international bestsellers such as Jessie Burton (The Miniaturist) to James Oswald, as well as social media favourites such as Very British Problems (@SoVeryBritish). Juliet is an agent in the UK literary department of UTA. She was highly commended in the Literary Agent of the Year category by the Bookseller in 2015, having been shortlisted in 2014. She tweets @mushenska. 
Peter Newman’s debut fantasy novel The Vagrant was published by HarperCollins in 2015 to critical acclaim and commercial success. Two further books and two short stories, featuring the same characters, will follow in 2016 and 2017. He tweets @runpetewrite. 
Ross Armstrong’s debut psychological thriller The Watcher will be published in January 2017 in the UK, Germany, Italy and Spain. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

If you’re a new writer, the process of getting your book into print might seem a bit daunting. This unique masterclass with leading literary agent Juliet Mushens will demystify the publishing process and reveal what agents look for in fiction submissions.

In the space of three hours, you’ll learn everything from how to prepare the perfect submissions package to how to edit your manuscript and pitch your novel to an agent. name.text: Understanding virtual reality: A masterclass with Dave Ranyard
name.html: Understanding virtual reality: A masterclass with Dave Ranyard

description.text:
Learn about cutting-edge technology, immersive computer games and the social challenges of virtual reality - a fascinating lecture with VR developer Dave Ranyard, in partnership with Goldsmiths University   
Virtual reality lets us experience a world different from the one we live in. And much like the disruptive technologies that came before it - from electricity to TV, computers and smartphones - there’s no longer any doubt that it will significantly impact the way we live.  
  
If you’re interested in the future of VR, don’t miss out on this fascinating lecture with Dave Ranyard, virtual reality developer and former studio head of Sony London. Over the course of the evening, you’ll learn about the past, present and future of VR, and gain a deeper understanding of its social potential.  
  
The evening will particularly appeal to those with an interest in computer games and development, as well as anyone interested in new cultural directions, cutting-edge technology, TV and entertainment. Tickets are limited so book your place now [hyperlink] - and learn how virtual reality will impact the ways we experience and interact with the worlds around us. 
  
This Masterclass is run in partnership with Goldsmiths, a constituent college within the University of London,specialising in the arts, design, social sciences and creative technology  
  
  
Speaker profile 
  
Dave Ranyard is a virtual reality developer, and former director of Sony’s computer games and entertainment studio in London. Most notably, he worked on the critically acclaimed game London Heist for Ps4 and Playstation VR, as well as a number of high profile games including The Getaway and Singstar. Dave has a PhD in artificial intelligence and, for over three years, has been carrying out pioneering work exploring VR’s potential. He holds seats on the BAFTA games committee and the Virtual World Congress advisory boards, among others, and tweets as @Dr__Dave.  
  
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Advanced data visualisation: A one-day workshop
name.html: Advanced data visualisation: A one-day workshop

description.text:
Learn practical strategies to improve the impact of your infographics and drive traffic to your website 
If you work with data, this hands-on masterclass with data visualisation expert Andy Pemberton will help you to improve the quality and impact of your infographics. Over the course of the day, you’ll learn advanced data visualisation techniques and take part in practical exercises to put what you learned into practice. Drawing upon examples of cutting-edge data visualisations and storytelling projects, Andy will offer expert advice on how you can use infographics to drive more traffic to your website and get real results for your business.  
Content 

Using design tools to create persuasive data visualisations
How to optimise your content for the web and social media
Knowing when to use adaptive design and responsive formats
The importance of relevance, timeliness, exclusivity and emotion in online and offline content
Best practice for data visualisation – and examples of cutting-edge case studies that got results
Practical exercises on pen and paper – create your own infographic using data you’ve brought to the session
Opportunities for feedback on work carried out during the class

Please note this is an advanced level class. It’s suitable for people who already work with data and want to improve their visualisations, or those who want to get a better response to their content on the web and social media 
What to bring  

You should bring your own laptop and charger to the class – no computers will be provided on the day


 
Please also bring along some data, which you’ll use during practical exercises. Pens and paper will be provided 

 
Tutor profile Andy Pemberton is a leading data visualisation and content expert, who has worked with the United Nations, Cisco, Aviva and many other international brands. He’s currently working on a book, website and set of infographics called What’s Next for Banks. He tweets @andypemberton. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website

name.text: Creating characters for your novel: A writing class with Louisa Young
name.html: Creating characters for your novel: A writing class with Louisa Young

description.text:
Discover how to create vivid characters for your novel or short stories at this informative class with Louisa Young, bestselling author of My Dear, I Wanted to Tell You and the forthcoming Devotion 
Take a moment to think of your favourite novels – chances are they feature vivid characters that leap off the page and into your imagination. If you want to learn how to create compelling characters for your novel or short stories, come along to this morning masterclass with Louisa Young. 
Known for her breathtakingly vivid characters, brimming with emotional conviction and bursting with life, Louisa is the award-winning author of eleven novels including The Heroes’ Welcome. During this informative writers’ workshop, you’ll learn how to transport characters into a fictional world, as well as how make your characters so  convincing and enticing that readers will want to follow them from novel to novel. 
Content 

Characterisation - an overview of the role of characters in the novel
Finding out the background of your characters - where do they come from? What makes them tick? Are they based on anyone in particular?
How to breathe life into your characters and transport them into a fictional world
Advice on letting your characters grow and lead their own story (without letting them get out of hand) 
Discovering how your characters relate to one another
What to do when your characters just sit there and do nothing
Q&A - a great opportunity to pick the brains of a bestselling novelist

Writing month curated by Lionel Shriver 
This Masterclass is part of a series of writing classes this April, specially curated by Lionel Shriver, internationally bestselling author of We Need to Talk About Kevin. Keep an eye on our website or sign up to the Guardian Masterclasses newsletter to be the first to hear about more classes in this exclusive series, taught by some of the UK’s finest writers and editors.  
Tutor profile 
Louisa Young is an award-winning novelist, short story writer and biographer. Her works include The Heroes’ Welcome, a follow up to the 2011 bestseller My Dear, I Wanted to Tell You, which was shortlisted for the Costa Novel Award and the Wellcome Book Prize, and was the first ever winner of the Galaxy Audiobook of the Year. Her eleventh novel, Devotion, will be published in spring 2016 by The Borough Press, HarperFiction’s literary fiction imprint. She tweets @rileypurefoy. 
Full course and returns information on the Masterclasses website
